column3: The fried chicken beats its competition at almost all the southern-food meccas up here.
A modest size, a stark decor, and a menu by Masato Shimizu, the talented young sushi chef who formerly worked at Jewel Bako.
When a dining establishment makes a good slice of pizza for 99 cents, the chances are excellent that thereÍs going to be a rabble of slavering slice hounds beating down its door.
Offering mediterranean and turkish cuisine with some great vegetarian options

These ñsophisticatedî yet ñaccessibleî Italians ñshineî thanks to chef Missy RobbinsÍ ñdelectableî cuisine backed up by ñcossetingî service; both the Flatiron original and Columbus Circle spin-off are ñcorporateî but ñcomfortableî, but thereÍs ñmore buzzî _ and a ñpark viewî _ at the larger TWC satellite.
An ambitious Italian menu that mixes the familiar and the obscure.
ælocal organic original environmentally conscious food. a new restaurant at abc carpet & home in nyc with chef jean georges vongerichten.

George MendesÍ ñastutely preparedî modern Med cooking focuses on Iberian Coast cuisine at this Flatiron ñfoodie destinationî; the best seats are at the bar facing the ñopen kitchenî, but wherever you land, count on a ñsleekî setting, savvy service and serious tabs.

Anita LoÍs tiny jewel-box restaurant on Barrow Street, which burned down three years ago, has been rebuilt from scratch, with the help of a feng shui master. The result has indeed been harmonious for the chef and her patrons alike. LoÍs famous foie gras soup dumplings and pigÍs trotter with chanterelles survive from the original menu, and her new creations (butter-poached lobster with sweet-pea flan, soft blocks of sablefish marinated in miso) are more focused and confident than ever. Combine this with the first-class service, the glowing little room, and the fact that Lo is in the kitchen almost every night, and you have a dining experience that strikes an increasingly rare balance among style, technique, and traditional gourmet pleasure.

ñSublimeî Scandinavian fare and the namesake spirit highlight this ñdistinctiveî Midtowner thatÍs enhanced by ñfirst-classî service and a ñsparseî, Nordic-ñchicî setting; though the prix fixe_only tabs are as ñstunningî as the cooking, the front cafe is ñless expensive.î
Hong Kong_style kitchen tucked under the Manhattan Bridge offers a wide-ranging menu and adds deep-fried minnows to the many joys of Chinatown.
Featuring favorite regional classics using imported ingredients
Affordable Italian flavors that is warm but also chic

ñGenuine, moan-provokingî Cantonese fare (ñamazing congeeî, ñoutstanding roast meatsî) explains the ñmob sceneî at this cash-only C-towner; given the ñinsanely inexpensiveî checks, itÍs easy to overlook the ñnonexistentî decor, ñrushedî service and unfortunate name.
Amazing Italian option with gracious hospitality that also offers gluten-free dishes

A locavore ñpioneerî, Dan BarberÍs ñsublimeî Village American is famed for its ñvibrant flavorsî and ñamazing ingredientsî bursting with ñstraight-from-the-farmî freshness; the ñcalmingî setting, ñabove-and-beyondî service and ñpeace-and-quietî acoustics help mute the ñexpensiveî tabs, though reservations are more ñdifficultî since ñBarack and Michelleî showed up.
One of the best restaurants for French cuisine, offering healthy fresh flavors

ñRefinedî dining comes to Lincoln Center-land via this ñfirst-classî yearling from Daniel Boulud, plying ñcreative interpretationsî of Med fare in an ñelegantî venue adjacent to Bar Boulud; its ñgrown-upî fan base digs the ñexquisiteî cooking and ñadroitî service, and the ñbig-bucksî tabs suggest thereÍs ñno sign of recession here.î

From David Bouley and the ñserious chefsî from OsakaÍs Tsuji Culinary Institute comes this ñhauteî TriBeCa Japanese, where ñbrilliantî, ñdetailî-oriented kaiseki spreads are ñsmoothlyî served in a ñsoothing, wood-envelopedî space arranged around an open kitchen; some say the ñlongî, ñelaborateî prix fixe_only meals are ñbetter than sexî, but the ñsmallî sushi bar area offers limited ö la carte foreplay.
Originally formed by a hotel chain in India, this restaurant offers great quality food. Very reasonably priced buffet

Daniel BouludÍs ñmagic touchî is in evidence at this UES ñclass actî, a showcase for chef Gavin KaysenÍs ñsophisticatedî, ñpristineî French cooking, ñimpeccably servedî in a ñcosmopolitanî milieu; the ñpremiumî pricing doesnÍt faze its ñupper-crustyî, ñold-moneyî crowd, but lesser mortals say the ñwonderful prix fixe lunchî is ña stealî at $37; P.S. thereÍs also a ñlovelyî lounge next door, Bar Pleiades, that shakes smart cocktails.

C_sar RamirezÍs Michelin-starred eighteen-seat tasting atelier in downtown Brooklyn just got its liquor license, and the reservation system is still a bit of a mess. The chef also has a slightly anachronistic fondness for the kind of grand ingredients (caviar, gold leaf, truffles) that used to define so-called gourmet dining in this town. But his most imaginative dishes (langoustines with salmon roe and burrata, any of his sashimi-style offerings) are as refined as anything youÍll find across the river, and the volume and range of his elaborate 25-course dinners justify the dizzying $225 sticker price.
Club A Steakhouse provides the feel of a steakhouse with a modern take, providing delicious wines and a distinct menu
Offers American and Italian cuisine through prix-fixed menus. Also has great wine

Drew Nieporent and his chef-partner, Paul Liebrandt, have scrapped the ö la carte menu at this Tribeca restaurant in favor of a more rarefied tasting option. I donÍt like the new format as much as the old one, but the best of LiebrandtÍs creations„intricately arranged tastes of Scottish red-legged partridge, delicately textured desserts like the pamplemousse meringue„are works of art. Add NieporentÍs old-world wine cellar and the restaurantÍs sleek, palate-cleansing design, and this is the closest thing youÍll find in this burger-ravaged metropolis to the high-end restaurant of tomorrow.

The filament lightbulbs at Tom ColicchioÍs endlessly imitated restaurant donÍt look quite as cutting-edge as they used to. But the classic farm-to-table menu still exudes a sense of austere, even biblical, authority, and almost everything on it tastes exceptional. Pay special attention to the simple, unadorned pleasures„the fat, milky Fanny Bay oysters from British Columbia, the ever-changing seasonal selection of hand-foraged mushrooms, and the impossibly sweet diver scallops, which were garnished, the last time I dropped by, with a simple bay leaf and served with a pot of vermouth butter on the side.
With amazing d_cor, this restaurant provides French cuisine cooked to perfection
Del Postoæis the ultimate expression of what an Italian restaurant should be.

Imagine pizza so incredibly delicious that New Yorkers and tourists-in-the-know happily stand in line for three hours to get a pie or even just a slice. WhatÍs the secret to such devotion? Dom DeMarcoÍs mouthwatering, award-winning pies are carefully handcrafted using closely guarded recipes and quality imported ingredients.

Located just steps away from the American Museum of Natural History and Central Park on ManhattanÍs Upper West Side, Dovetail offers an intimate dining experience showcasing Chef John FraserÍs award-winning contemporary American cuisine and creative use of seasonal, farm-fresh ingredients. Dovetail received three stars fromæThe New York Timesæas well as its first Michelin star in 2011.

"Disneyland for foodies", this "larger-than-life" Flatiron food hall via the Batali-Bastianich team celebrates "everything Italian", offering noshing at counters vending cheese, coffee, fish, gelato, pasta, pizza, vegetables and wine, all in the "middle of a grocery store" the size of "Grand Central Station"; the "price of success" includes "extreme crowds", "no available seats" and "sensory overload", but then again, there's "nothing else like it anywhere."
A completely new take on food, this restaurant provides you with a list of 16 ingredients from which the staff design a meal

ñAlways busyî, this ñlaid-backî Village/UWS duo dishes out ñbasicî, if ñuninspiringî, French chow for ñmoderateî dough; a 24/7 open-door policy is the secret to their success, not the ñsnottyî service and ñglorified coffee-shopî decor.
Offering new American cuisine with great atmosphere and promises a sophisticated experience
Offers new and innovative American cuisine providing price fixed menus for dinner and a la carte for lunch
Coal fired pizza in the heart of Brooklyn

Mediterranean fine dining at Il Buco in New York is a true gourmet experience. A fusion of Italian and Spanish flavors blends to create seasonal delicacies and handmade artisanal pastas. With an award-winning wine list, critically acclaimed Il Buco serves up sublime tapas-style dishes and entrees in a homely dining room with country-style charm.

The world headquarters of the _ever-expanding empire of Jean-Georges Vongerichten drops from the top ten on our list mainly because the boss seems more interested in farm-to-table dishes than in Asian-fusion cooking these days. On my last visit to the gleaming glass dining room, the chunk of beef tenderloin I ordered for lunch was strangely chewy and even bled on the plate, and a few too many of the _dishes we sampled (sea scallops draped over soggy crisped rice, sticky crab dumplings flavored with Meyer-lemon tea) seemed like fusion for fusionÍs sake.

The atmosphere is ñhushedî at this East Village Japanese vegetarian where ancient Buddhist shojin cuisine is served kaiseki-style and priced ñas if it were Harry Winston jewelsî; a ñZenî mood and ñphenomenalî service round out the ñalternate-universeî experience.
Katz's Delicatessen is a kosher-style delicatessen restaurant founded in 1888. Katz's Deli is a New York landmark famous for its pastrami sandwiches and hot dogs.
æPizzas are cooked using a wood burning domed brick oven and bufalo mozzarella imported from Italy.
This French seafood restaurant provides simple but delectable cooking while also providing luxury options
A great place to sit down and have some amazing coffee and delicious French desserts
Amazing bakery in the middle of NYC that offers a taste of Paris

ñMaestroî Danny Meyer ñhits all the right notesî at this ñenergeticî take on the Roman trattoria, where ñsoul-satisfyingî Italiana (including the eponymous roast baby pig) and trademark ñinformed, caringî service come in ñcomfortableî environs that ñstrike the right balance between casual and formalî; yes, the ñcheckÍs a little steepî and itÍs ñtough to get a rezî, but itÍs an NYC ñmust.î

Marea Ristorante, located in one of Manhattans most storied addresses, features Chef Michael White's ode to Italian seafood. From his trademark handmade pastas to his fresh crudo and whole fish, Chef White is committed to reinventing the notion of seafood in New York.
Masayoshi Takayama's restaurant in the Time Warner Center has been a temple of sushi since it opened in 2004.

Is Keith McNallyÍs semi-private faux-speakeasy dining club really one of the top fifteen restaurants in town? After careful reconsideration (we gave it two stars in our 2009 review), we think so. The faux speakeasy is the dominant dining genre of our recessionary times, after all. And thereÍs no denying the quality of Riad NasrÍs high-wire bistro cooking (get the celebrated Black Label burger, the beautifully crisped pork trotter, or anything from the excellent grillades section of the menu), or McNallyÍs uncanny ability to conjure that ineffable feeling among his selected guests that on this particular night, in this particular room, theyÍre dining in the right place, at the right time.

The arcane Internet-reservation system is harder to crack than Fort Knox, and if you actually manage to obtain a seat at this spare, twelve-seat East Village dining bar, the overly reverent atmosphere among the assembled food geeks can have a slightly chilling effect. But once dinner begins, the dazzling forward-thinking cooking makes all of that worth putting up with. To experience the full range of David ChangÍs uniquely modern, slightly mad post-gourmet sensibility (delicately broken eggs oozing caviar; the famous frozen foie gras grated over Riesling gel_e), fork over $175 for the legendary lunchtime tasting extravaganza (Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays). It lasts three hours, which leaves plenty of time for a digestive late-afternoon nap.
A beautiful eatery on Mulberry St in Little Italy serving the finest pasta, seafood and veal. Join us for lunch or dinner 7 days a week.
The original TriBeCa hangout for the hip and fabulous.

Every once in a while, Manhattan delivers a hole-in-the-wall taqueria that does our neighbors south of the border justice. PanchitoÍs never pretends to be that place. Instead, this neighborhood cantina promotes a summer-break-in-Baja cuisine for which the main course is the Margarita. Amid mismatched leather and canvas couches or sequestered off in a booth made from discarded van seats, partying NYU undergrads, FIT designers-in-training, and aspiring librarians from Parsons spill over into three expansive rooms where the pleasantly dilapidated ambiance is lit by punched-tin lights and decorated with Oregon Trail accessories. (Check out the time on the banjo clock.) As for the food, the greasy and generous portions of Tex-Mex classics„burritos, nachos, fajitas„are designed to satisfy alcohol-induced cravings exclusively.æ

Why donÍt we put Thomas KellerÍs consistently excellent, extravagantly praised establishment at the top of our Best Restaurants list like every other blogger, gourmand, and overfed critic in town? Because despite all sorts of subtle changes in recent years, the staid, icy room still reminds me more of a hushed stage set than an organic big-city restaurant. And while the cooking is technically immaculate in every way, the highlights of KellerÍs fabled (and increasingly pricey) tasting menu„the velvet-smooth foie gras torchons, the butter-poached lobster from Nova Scotia, the famous Oysters and Pearls„tend to feature tricks and ingredients weÍve seen before.

A ñtimeless classicî for ñold-fashioned pamperingî, Terry BrennanÍs ñtop-drawerî Lincoln Center_area ñdestinationî is a ñrefinedî ñmarriageî of ñmagnifiqueî French-Med fare (concluding with an ñunbelievableî cheese course) and ñexemplary serviceî in a ñlovelyî, ñadultî setting; ñcostlyî it is, but itÍs ñworth cracking open the piggy bankî for what is always a satisfying experience.

In 1972, the first ñPongsri" Thai Restaurant launched in the heart of Chinatown, New York City as well as 2 other locations since then. As far as Thai Restaurants go, we are the best NYC has to offer.

ñClassic Austrianî cuisine gets a ñplayful twistî and a ñseasonalî spin at this ñrefinedî Midtowner overseen by a ñwell-trainedî staff; some wonder ñwhy itÍs not more belovedî given its ñconvenient locationî near Carnegie Hall and City Center _ ñexpensiveî tabs may be a clue.
Offers great desserts, including the trademarked Frozen Hot Chocolate along with food options

ItÍs a ñparadise for uni-loversî, but just ñdonÍt tell anybodyî plead partisans of chef Sotohiro KosugiÍs ñtinyî, ñunderstatedî, somewhat under-the-radar West Village Japanese known for its ñurchin artistryî; its ñexquisiteî sushi ñwould stand up to any in Tokyoî, but comes ñwith prices to match.î

The ñomakase is off the hookî at this ñinnovativeî Japanese quartet from chef Gari Sugio, whose ñbutteryî, ñetherealî sushi amounts to ñbite-size works of artî; though the settings are austere and the morsels ñexpensiveî, purists pronounce the experience ñworth every last pennyî; P.S. the new takeout-oriented Plaza Food Hall satellite is cheaper.

Despite losing its eponymous chef, this ñstunningî Grand Central_area Japanese standout is still serving sushi thatÍs among ñNYCÍs bestî; equally ñflawlessî service in ñsimpleî blond-wood digs help justify the ñexpensiveî tabs _ though the $23 dinner prix fixe ñmay be the best dealî in town.
Nestled in the heart of Chinatown, this inexpensive bakery is extremely popular by the locals

ñNorthern Spainî comes to ñNuevo Yorkî via this Villager from Seamus Mullen (ex Boqueria) where ñfabulousî tapas and ñBasque cider on tapî are dispensed in ñrusticî ñstone-walled-tavernî digs; itÍs a ñmuy calienteî ñsceneî with ñhigh pricesî and a no-rez policy that ñmeans a long waitî, but amigos insist itÍs ñworth it.î

column1: The Breslin Bar and Dining Room
column3: ñSceney but satisfyingî, this ñdark, woodyî Ace Hotel destination from Ken Friedman and April Bloomfield offers ñheavenlyî ñmeat in all of its formsî on its ñdecadentî British menu, but the ñbeautifulî ñhipsterî crowd steals the ñshowî; ñnoiseî, ñtoo-cool-for-schoolî service and no rez_induced ñwaitsî come with the territory.

ñOld-school West Villageî dining thrives at this circa-1977 ñcharmerî with a ñyoga vibeî, offering ñperfectly acceptableî Franco-American fare and a ñcheap and cheerfulî brunch; although ñstarting to show its ageî, it gets ñbonusî points for the ñcoolî performance space downstairs.

Danny MeyerÍs MoMA ñmarvelî presents the ñultimateî in museum dining, with chef Gabriel KreutherÍs ñwork-of-artî French_New American cuisine arriving at table via a ñterrificî ñproî staff in ñbeautifulî Bauhaus-influenced confines; itÍs divided between a ñlivelyî, ñcasualî front barroom offering ñless-expensiveî ö la carte small plates and a ñformalî prix fixe_only back room where the ñimpressive sculpture garden viewî is factored into the bill.
The prix fixe dinner's a tremendous bargain, and a serious delight. In the realm of red-sauce cooking, it's nothing short of revolutionary.

ñDanny MeyerÍs original flagshipî in Union Square has locked up ñforever-favoriteî status, accruing perennial ñaccoladesî for its ñexpertly preparedî ñGreenmarketî-driven New American cuisine, ñaffable, unpretentiousî service and ñsubdued, stylishî digs; the experience is ñworth every pennyî, and while scoring a rez ñisnÍt always easyî, you can always ñeat at the bar.î

Madcap genius Wylie DufresneÍs pioneering Lower East Side restaurant drops several spaces (and loses a star) because some of his molecular-gastronomic tricks„foie gras falafel„donÍt seem quite as novel as they used to, when that style of cooking was all the rage. And because the desserts have fallen off since the great pastry wizard, Alex Stupak, left to open a taco shop.

ñStunning views on all four sidesî draw ñelegantî types to this enduring Midtown aerie with an ñold-NY feelî thatÍs ñperfect for a romantic interludeî; being ñoff the beaten pathî makes it ñless touristyî than other well-known rooftops, but the ñexpensive drinksî mean itÍs best to go as ñsomeoneÍs guest.î

ñItÍs all aboutî the ñmagicalî atmosphere at this ñstylishî multilevel Chelsea hot spot whose ñlovelyî glassed-in garden feels like ñCentral Park indoorsî; the Med menu is ñaverageî and the service iffy, but most donÍt mind since you ñgo for the ambianceî and ñHigh Line proximity.î
A great place to go on a romantic date with a special someone. Features great pizzas, mac and cheese
A place with great night life to go on a romantic date with your special someone.
Il Posto Accanto is an elegantly decorated wine bar with an extensive Italian small plates menu served by a friendly a knowledgeable staff. We offer an extensive international wine list.

ñAs the name would implyî, this ñtrendy TriBeCanî from nightlife czar Matt Abramcyk and former NY Ranger Sean Avery is indeed ñtinyî, though the ñrustic, bohemianî decor tilts more ñcuteî than ñcrampedî; the American menu is likewise ñsmallî, but showcases an ñawesomeî burger served late.
A restaurant which offers tofu tempura, flet mignon, beef dumplings and other mediterranean style dishes.

From La SirneÍs well-loved owner comes this petite, pricey BYO (recently relocated next door to the mothership), specializing in fondue, including cheese, meat and chocolate versions; itÍs a ready-made date place, with plush banquettes and French music enhancing the sensuous experience; P.S. two people required per pot, priced per person.
